'''''Leucopaxillus albissimus''''' is a species of [[mushroom]] that lives as a [[Saprotrophic nutrition|saprobe]], decaying the litter under [[Conifer|coniferous trees]]. It produces a large white fruiting body that is unusually resistant to decay.<ref name="urlRogers">{{cite web|url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6336.asp|title=Rogers Mushrooms ; Mushroom Pictures & Mushroom Reference|accessdate=2009-06-18|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704141421/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6336.asp|archivedate=2008-07-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Leucopaxillus_albissimus.html|title=California Fungi—Leucopaxillus albissimus|last=Wood |first=Michael|author2=Fred Stevens |publisher=MykoWeb|accessdate=2009-06-18}}</ref> It is not considered to be [[edible mushroom|edible]].

==Description==
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of ''Leucopaxillus albissimus'' is 4–20 cm wide, and slowly changes from convex to plane; occasionally the disc is depressed. When young, the margin is incurved and faintly striate. The cap's surface is dry, unpolished, and smooth; in moderate weather, it becomes scaled and a shade of cream to cream-buff.<ref>McKenny et al.: p. 83</ref> As it ages, the cap's surface turns buff-tan. Overall, the [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white, moderately thick, and has a mild odor.<ref name="Expert">{{cite web|url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/leucopaxillus_albissimus.html|title=Leucopaxillus albissimus|last=Kuo|first=M.|date=February 2007|publisher=MushroomExpert.Com |accessdate=2009-06-18}}</ref> [[lamella (mycology)|Gills]] are crowded, broad, and [[decurrent]]. Although they are originally cream-colored, the gills turn buff-tan with age.<ref>Arora (1986) p. 167</ref> Varying from 3–7 cm in length, the [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] of ''Leucopaxillus albissimus'' is 2.5–4 cm thick, stout, and often enlarged at the base. The surface of the stipe varies from smooth to finely-scaled and is a cream color when young; it may turn buff-tan in age. When handled, it bruises pale buff-brown at the base.<ref>Arora (1991): p. 58</ref>

''Leucopaxillus albissimus'' has a white [[spore print]]. The elliptical [[basidiospore|spores]] are ornamented with [[Amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]] warts. The spores measure 5–7 x 3.5–5 [[micrometre|µm]].<ref name=Lincoff1981>{{cite book |author=Lincoff GH| title=The Audubon Society field guide to North American mushrooms | year=1981 | publisher=Alfred A. Knopf | isbn=0-394-51992-2}}</ref>
[[File:Leucopaxillus albissimus spores.jpg|thumb|Leucopaxillus albissimus spores]]

===Habitat===
Primarily residing under [[conifer]]s and hardwoods, ''Leucopaxillus albimissus'' is often scattered or gregarious in arcs or rings. It fruits from mid to late winter in California, and in autumn in other parts of North America.<ref>Miller: sp. 160</ref>
